questions.text: An investigator is studying the effect of exercise on athletes between the ages of 20 and 30 years. The participants are asked to run for 15 minutes on a treadmill. During the session, their temperature, blood pressure, and pulse are monitored at 2-minute intervals. An echocardiogram is performed at minute 10 of the experiment. Which of the following physiologic responses to exercise is most likely to be observed in this study?

choices.text: Increased cutaneous vasoconstriction due to acetylcholine release
Increased pulmonary vascular resistance due to epinephrine release
Increased heart rate due to norepinephrine release
Decreased stroke volume due to epinephrine release
Decreased cardiac venous return due to dopamine release

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exercise stimulates the sympathetic nervous system, which initially causes peripheral vasoconstriction via noradrenergic stimulation. However, as exercise continues, temperature reflexes activate cutaneous vasodilation in order to dissipate the heat being generated by muscle activity. This process is mediated by acetylcholine from sympathetic cholinergic innervation and most commonly results in the release of nitric oxide.

B) INCORRECT:

Exercise increases sympathetic tone, which causes an increase in cardiac output and thus an increase in intravascular volume in both the systemic as well as pulmonary circulation. The increase in volume causes dilation of pulmonary arteries and recruitment of pulmonary capillaries, both of which lower overall pulmonary vascular resistance.

C) CORRECT:

Exercise stimulates the sympathetic nervous system, which leads to an increase in systemic catecholamine release (e.g., epinephrine, norepinephrine) from the adrenal medulla. By binding to β1 receptors on cardiac cells throughout the heart, catecholamines trigger a signaling cascade that leads to increases in heart rate (positive chronotropy), contractility (positive inotropy), and conduction velocity (positive dromotropy), as well as dilation of the coronary arteries. Exercise also decreases parasympathetic tone (vagal tone), which normally has a negative chronotropic effect on the sinus node. This combination of sympathetic activation and parasympathetic withdrawal contributes to the increased heart rate that occurs physiologically during exercise.

Norepinephrine (NE) causes a marked increase in systemic vascular resistance because of its higher affinity for α1 receptors compared to β1 receptors. Although NE initially increases heart rate, it eventually induces reflex bradycardia due to stimulation of baroreceptors, which mitigates its chronotropic effects. Over time, the effects of NE on peripheral vascular resistance can result in an overall decrease in heart rate.

D) INCORRECT:

Exercise stimulates the sympathetic nervous system, which increases systemic catecholamine (e.g., epinephrine and norepinephrine) release. By binding to β1 receptors on the heart, catecholamines trigger a signaling cascade that leads to several physiologic changes, including increased contractility (positive inotropy) and conduction velocity (positive dromotropy). A decrease in stroke volume is not seen during normal exercise and would potentially lead to hypotension and syncope.

E) INCORRECT:

Activation of the sympathetic nervous system increases systemic catecholamine (e.g., epinephrine and norepinephrine) release. Epinephrine and norepinephrine stimulate venous vasoconstriction, which leads to increased, not decreased, cardiac venous return. In addition, skeletal muscle contraction compresses the veins and thereby further increases this effect. Dopamine does not play a significant role in the increased venous return seen as a physiologic response to exercise.
questions.hint: Physiologic changes in exercise occur due to a combination of withdrawal of the parasympathetic nervous system and activation of the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: An investigator is developing a new medication that can be given for acute relief of bronchospasm in patients with acute asthma exacerbations. Some of the patients who received this drug reported developing transitory tremors as an adverse effect. This drug is most likely to have which of the following additional effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of β2 receptors on skeletal muscle increases rather than decreases glycogenolysis. Increased glycogenolysis provides glucose from stored glycogen to produce downstream ATP needed for increased muscle use during a fight-or-flight response.

B) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of β2 receptors in the GI tract decreases rather than increases peristalsis, which leads to decreased GI motility and delayed digestion during a fight-or-flight response. With a decrease in digestion, blood can instead be preferentially used by other systems, for example, skeletal muscle for contraction. Conversely, stimulation of muscarinic (primarily M3) receptors in the GI tract increases peristalsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of muscarinic (primarily M3) receptors on the bladder detrusor muscle results in contraction. In contrast, stimulation of β2 receptors causes relaxation of certain smooth muscles, including the bladder detrusor.

β3 receptors are the predominant receptor subtype present in the urinary bladder; however, all three receptor subtypes (β1, β2, β3) are present.

D) CORRECT:

Stimulation of β2 receptors causes relaxation of smooth muscle fibers, including in the blood vessels, which results in peripheral vasodilation. Other consequences of relaxation of smooth muscle fibers include decreased uterine tone and bladder detrusor relaxation (in the bladder, relaxation occurs mostly through the stimulation of β3 receptors).

See “Overview of sympathomimetic effects” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of β2 receptors in the uterus leads to decreased rather than increased uterine tone. β2 agonists like terbutaline are given to diminish uterine contractions in preterm labor. Conversely, stimulation of α1 receptors mediates uterine contraction.
questions.hint: Tremors are the most common adverse effect of β2 receptor agonists, which are given to patients with asthma for the acute relief of bronchospasm.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the principles of cell-to-cell signaling of the autonomic nervous system. It is found that the adrenal medulla has receptors that, when activated, result in the immediate opening of Na+, Ca2+, and K+ channels, which subsequently leads to the secretion of epinephrine and norepinephrine. These receptors are structurally most similar to which of the following receptors?

choices.text: M3 receptors of the sweat glands
Alpha 1 receptors of the bladder neck
D2 receptors of the basal ganglia
NM receptors of the quadriceps femoris muscle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

H2 receptors of the stomach are histamine receptors that increase gastric acid secretion by parietal cells. In contrast to the ligand-gated channel structure seen in the receptors of the adrenal medulla, H2 receptors are chronotropic receptors, meaning they act via the cAMP pathway to stimulate adenylate cyclase and increase its activity.

B) INCORRECT:

Beta 2 receptors (β2) of the lungs are adrenergic receptors responsible for the relaxation of bronchial smooth muscles. In contrast to the ligand-gated channel structure seen in the receptors of the adrenal medulla, β2 receptors are Gs protein-coupled receptors, meaning they act via the cAMP pathway to stimulate adenylate cyclase and increase its activity.

C) INCORRECT:

M3 receptors of the sweat glands are muscarinic acetylcholine receptors of the sympathetic pathway that promote diaphoresis. In contrast to the ligand-gated channel structure seen in the receptors of the adrenal medulla, M3 receptors are Gq protein-coupled receptors, meaning they act via the inositol triphosphate pathway to increase intracytoplasmic calcium concentration.

D) INCORRECT:

Alpha 1 receptors (α1) of the bladder neck are adrenergic receptors that promote contraction of smooth muscles, enhancing urinary continence. In contrast to the ligand-gated channel structure seen in the receptors of the adrenal medulla, α1 receptors are Gq protein-coupled receptors, meaning they act via the inositol triphosphate pathway to increase intracytoplasmic calcium concentration.

E) INCORRECT:

M2 receptors of the heart are muscarinic acetylcholine receptors that have a negative chronotropic effect and reduce atrial contractility. In contrast to the ligand-gated channel structure seen in the receptors of the adrenal medulla, M2 receptors are Gi protein-coupled receptors, meaning they act via the cAMP pathway to decrease adenylate cyclase activity.

F) INCORRECT:

D2 receptors of the basal ganglia are dopaminergic receptors that inhibit the indirect pathway of movement. In contrast to the ligand-gated channel structure seen in the receptors of the adrenal medulla, D2 receptors are Gi protein-coupled receptors, meaning they act via the cAMP pathway to decrease adenylate cyclase activity.

G) CORRECT:

NM receptors at the neuromuscular junction of the skeletal muscle are structurally similar to the NN receptors of the autonomic ganglia and adrenal medulla. NM and NN both belong to a subclass of receptors known as nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (i.e., acetylcholine receptors that contain ligand-gated Na+/K+ channels that are activated by nicotine). Activation of NM receptors of the quadriceps femoris muscle results in depolarization at the motor end plate and, subsequently, muscle contraction.
questions.hint: The studied receptors in the adrenal medulla are ligand-gated ion channels of the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: An investigator is studying physiological changes in the autonomic nervous system in response to different stimuli. 40 μg of epinephrine is infused in a healthy volunteer over a period of 5 minutes, and phenoxybenzamine is subsequently administered. Which of the following effects is most likely to be observed in this volunteer?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine stimulates glycogen breakdown in skeletal muscle by agonism at beta-2 adrenergic receptors. Skeletal muscle does not express alpha-adrenergic receptors, therefore this effect of epinephrine will be unaffected by the administration of phenoxybenzamine and muscle glycogenolysis will remain unchanged.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased synthesis of aqueous humor by the ciliary body would be consistent with the use of an alpha-2 receptor agonist, such as epinephrine. However, phenoxybenzamine blocks the alpha-adrenergic effects of epinephrine, resulting in a predominance of the beta-adrenergic effects of epinephrine and a subsequent increase in aqueous humor secretion (via beta-2 receptor effects).

C) INCORRECT:

Increased peripheral vascular resistance due to vascular smooth muscle contraction would be consistent with the use of an alpha-1 receptor agonist, such as epinephrine. However, in this case, phenoxybenzamine blocks the alpha-adrenergic effects of epinephrine. The beta-2 receptor agonism of epinephrine would thus predominate, resulting in a decrease in vascular resistance.

D) INCORRECT:

Lipolysis in adipose tissue is stimulated by agonism at beta-1, 2, and 3 adrenergic receptors, and inhibited by agonism at the alpha-2 receptors. When the alpha-adrenergic effects of epinephrine are blocked by phenoxybenzamine the beta-adrenergic effects will predominate, leading to increased lipolysis

E) CORRECT:

Insulin secretion is inhibited by alpha-2 receptor agonism and stimulated by beta-2 receptor agonism on pancreatic cells. The alpha-adrenergic effects of epinephrine are blocked by phenoxybenzamine, which blocks both alpha-1 and alpha-2 receptors irreversibly. As a result, the beta-adrenergic effects of epinephrine on the pancreas would predominate, leading to an increase in insulin secretion.

F) INCORRECT:

Detrusor muscle contraction is inhibited by agonism at beta-3 receptors, whereas alpha-1 receptor agonism stimulates contraction of the bladder neck only. When the alpha-adrenergic effects of epinephrine are blocked by phenoxybenzamine the beta-adrenergic effects will predominate, leading to decreased intravesical pressure and decreased bladder outflow resistance.

Increased pressure within the bladder due to detrusor muscle contraction can also occur with stimulation of the muscarinic-3 receptor, which is innervated by the parasympathetic nervous system.
questions.hint: At this moderate dose, epinephrine is a non-selective adrenergic agonist. Phenoxybenzamine is an irreversible alpha-adrenergic antagonist.

questions.text: An investigator is studying brachial artery reactivity in women with suspected coronary heart disease. The brachial artery diameter is measured via ultrasound before and after intra-arterial injection of acetylcholine. An increase of 7% in the vascular diameter is noted. The release of which of the following is most likely responsible for the observed effect?

choices.text: Atrial natriuretic peptide from atrial myocytes
Neuropeptide Y from sympathetic nerve endings

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The release of nitric oxide (an endothelial-derived relaxation factor) from endothelial cells is caused by acetylcholine and is responsible for the vasodilatory effect seen here. The binding of acetylcholine to its receptors on endothelial cells results in the activation of nitric oxide synthase, which catalyzes the production of nitric oxide from L-arginine. Nitric oxide, in turn, activates guanylyl cyclase, which increases cGMP synthesis. The end result of this cascade is arterial smooth muscle relaxation and subsequent dilation of the vessel.
Image Description:

NO (nitrogen oxide) is a small reactive molecule with a half-life of only a few seconds that diffuses freely across membranes and serves a unique role as signaling messenger. NO is mainly released by endothelial cells, where it is synthesized from L-arginine by NO synthase, which is activated by an increase of calcium levels in the cell.
Once synthesized, NO can activate the soluble enzyme guanylate cyclase, which is present in the cytosol and converts GTP into cGMP, in downstream cells (e.g., muscle cells). cGMP acts as a messenger and activates protein kinases (e.g., PKG) until it is transformed into GMP by a phosphodiesterase and thus deactivated.

B) INCORRECT:

The release of endothelin from the peripheral vasculature (e.g., secondary to vascular damage) results in vasoconstriction (rather than vasodilation) of the peripheral vessels.

C) INCORRECT:

The release of serotonin from neuroendocrine cells, such as intestinal enterochromaffin cells, results in vasoconstriction (rather than vasodilation) of peripheral vessels. Moreover, the release of serotonin is not stimulated by acetylcholine. Further effects of serotonin include increased gastrointestinal motility, bronchoconstriction, and platelet aggregation.

D) INCORRECT:

The release of norepinephrine from the adrenal medulla occurs in response to the release of acetylcholine from preganglionic sympathetic fibers. However, norepinephrine causes vasoconstriction (rather than vasodilation) due to the activation of α1-adrenergic receptors.

E) INCORRECT:

The release of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) from atrial myocytes causes peripheral vasodilation mediated by an increase in cGMP concentrations in smooth muscle cells. Although this experiment showed peripheral vasodilation, ANP release is not stimulated by acetylcholine but is, rather, a result of increased stretch on the atrium (e.g., due to arterial hypertension). Further effects of ANP include decreased renal sodium reabsorption and increased diuresis.

F) INCORRECT:

The release of neuropeptide Y from sympathetic nerve endings results in appetite stimulation, regulation of anxiety-related behaviors, neuronal excitability, and vasoconstriction (rather than vasodilation) of peripheral vessels.
questions.hint: Acetylcholine is released from cholinergic nerve fibers. While the parasympathetic nervous system does not directly innervate the peripheral vasculature, it can cause vasodilation via the release of another substance, which in turn induces the relaxation of smooth muscle cells in the vessel wall via the action of cGMP.

questions.text: An investigator is developing a drug that results in contraction of the pupillary dilator muscle when instilled topically. The drug works by increasing neurotransmitter release from the presynaptic nerve terminal. When administered intravenously, this drug is most likely to have which of the following additional effects?

choices.text: Relaxation of the bladder neck sphincter
Release of epinephrine by the adrenal medulla
Secretion of sweat by exocrine glands

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased gut peristalsis occurs in response to acetylcholine release from the postganglionic parasympathetic fibers in the muscularis externa (Auerbach plexus). The drug mentioned here works by increasing norepinephrine release from the ends of postganglionic sympathetic fibers, which would be expected to cause a decrease in peristalsis.

B) INCORRECT:

Relaxation of the bladder neck sphincter occurs in response to decreased release of norepinephrine from the ends of postganglionic sympathetic fibers or blockade of the norepinephrine receptors (alpha-1 receptors) found on the bladder neck. The drug in question, which increases norepinephrine release from postganglionic sympathetic fibers, would have the opposite effect and cause contraction of the bladder neck sphincter.

C) INCORRECT:

The release of epinephrine by the adrenal medulla occurs in response to the release of acetylcholine from preganglionic sympathetic fibers. Epinephrine then acts on target tissues to produce a sympathetic response. The drug in question works by directly increasing norepinephrine release from the ends of postganglionic sympathetic fibers.
Image Description:

Innervation (left) and synaptic signaling of chromaffin cells (right) in the adrenal medulla.

1 and 2: Preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the thoracic spine directly innervate the chromaffin cells, which are neuroendocrine cells similar in structure to sympathetic neurons.
3. An action potential opens a voltage-gated calcium channel.
4. The increased calcium ion concentration within the synaptic cell triggers the release of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) from vesicles into the synaptic cleft.
5. The nicotinic ACh receptors on the chromaffin cells are ligand-gated ion channels. The influx of sodium ions triggers depolarization of the cell, which leads to the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels.
6. The increased calcium ion concentration within the chromaffin cell triggers the secretion of norepinephrine and epinephrine from the secretory granules into the bloodstream. Approx. 80% of chromaffin cells produce epinephrine, while only 20% produce norepinephrine.
7. The predominant serum catecholamine is norepinephrine (80%). This increase in serum norepinephrine occurs because norepinephrine is also secreted as a neurotransmitter by the postganglionic fibers from the sympathetic trunk, while epinephrine is produced almost exclusively by the adrenal gland.

D) INCORRECT:

Secretion of sweat by exocrine glands occurs in response to increased acetylcholine release from the ends of postganglionic sympathetic fibers. The drug in question also works by increasing the release of a neurotransmitter from postganglionic sympathetic fibers, but the neurotransmitter is norepinephrine rather than acetylcholine.

E) CORRECT:

Contraction of the pupillary dilator occurs in response to increased acetylcholine release from the ends of preganglionic sympathetic fibers at the superior cervical ganglion and, subsequently, increased norepinephrine release from the ends of postganglionic sympathetic fibers within the pupillary dilator muscle. Since this drug caused pupillary dilator contraction when instilled topically, its most likely mechanism of action is the direct stimulation of norepinephrine release. Norepinephrine, which is an adrenergic agonist, has the highest affinity for alpha-1 receptors. Besides pupillary dilator contraction, the other effects of alpha-1 stimulation include vasoconstriction, contraction of the bladder sphincter, and contraction of all intestinal sphincters including the pyloric sphincter.
Image Description:

Somatic motor neurons in the central nervous system (CNS) synapse directly onto skeletal muscle. In contrast, in most visceral (autonomic) motor pathways, a neuron in the CNS (preganglionic neuron) synapses onto a neuron in a peripheral ganglion (postganglionic neuron), which, in turn, synapses onto the target organ. The sympathetic ganglia are paravertebral and prevertebral, while the parasympathetic ganglia are located close to the target organs.

Somatic motor neurons release acetylcholine, as do all autonomic preganglionic neurons and parasympathetic postganglionic neurons. Most sympathetic postganglionic neurons release norepinephrine.

Exceptions (special variants):

- The adrenal medulla is directly innervated by preganglionic sympathetic neurons and releases catecholamines into the circulation, which exert hormonal effects on target tissues and organs.
- Sympathetic postganglionic neurons synapsing on eccrine sweat glands release acetylcholine.
questions.hint: The pupillary dilator muscle is a smooth muscle that is innervated by sympathetic fibers.

questions.text: After a near-miss car accident, a 30-year-old man experiences tachycardia, pale skin, and trembling. Which mechanism best explains his acute stress response?

choices.text: Elevated parasympathetic outflow decreasing heart rate
Increased norepinephrine release via thoracolumbar sympathetic terminals
Attenuated sympathetic tone from the spinal cord

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated parasympathetic activity decreases heart rate and is associated with the 'rest and digest' state. The patient's symptoms of tachycardia, pale skin, and trembling indicate sympathetic activation, not parasympathetic activity.

B) CORRECT:

During acute stress, the sympathetic nervous system activates through preganglionic neurons in the thoracolumbar region (T1-L2) of the spinal cord. These neurons stimulate postganglionic fibers to release norepinephrine at target organs. Norepinephrine binds to adrenergic receptors, causing physiological effects such as increased heart rate and contractility via β1-adrenergic receptors in the heart, and vasoconstriction in the skin via α-adrenergic receptors, leading to pallor. Additionally, norepinephrine affects skeletal muscles, contributing to trembling. This adrenergic response underlies the 'fight or flight' reaction.

Key learning point: The sympathetic nervous system is activated in response to stress, preparing the body for 'fight or flight' by increasing heart rate and energy mobilization.

C) INCORRECT:

Attenuated sympathetic tone would lead to bradycardia and vasodilation, not tachycardia, pale skin, and trembling. The acute stress response involves increased sympathetic activation, not a reduction in sympathetic tone.

D) INCORRECT:

Reduced epinephrine secretion would blunt the fight-or-flight response, leading to decreased heart rate and vasodilation. The symptoms of tachycardia, pale skin, and trembling indicate increased epinephrine release, not a reduction.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of urinary leakage over the past year. She reports involuntarily losing small amounts of urine after experiencing a sudden need to void. She has difficulty making it to the bathroom in time, and only feels comfortable going out into public if she has documented the location of all nearby restrooms. She also has begun to wake up at night to urinate. These symptoms have persisted despite 6 months of bladder training and weight loss, and reducing soda and coffee intake. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most likely to be effective in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Antimuscarinic agents such as oxybutynin antagonize parasympathetic muscarinic M3 receptors found in the bladder. Muscarinic M3 receptor stimulation is responsible for bladder contraction; thus, inhibition leads to improvement of symptoms in patients with urge incontinence. Pharmacotherapy should be reserved as an additional therapeutic option for patients in which behavioral therapy and lifestyle modifications alone were insufficient. Because muscarinic M3 receptors are located in various glands and in smooth muscles, anticholinergic agents have several systemic side effects, including pupillary dilation, dry mouth, constipation, tachycardia, and impaired cognition. They should be used with caution in patients predisposed to delirium (e.g., elderly patients). Beta-3 agonists, such as mirabegron, can be used to treat urge incontinence in patients who do not tolerate or have contraindications to antimuscarinic therapy.

See “Overview of sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system receptors” table.
Image Description:

Depicted here are the subtypes of adrenergic receptors (α and β) and cholinergic receptors (M: muscarinic, N: nicotinic), which trigger the organ response described when activated. The sympathetic chain is represented by the yellow chain of ganglia to the left of the spinal cord. Also depicted are cranial nerves (CN III, VII, IX, X) emerging from the brainstem.

B) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1 antagonists such as tamsulosin are commonly prescribed to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia, a condition that may cause overflow incontinence secondary to urinary retention in men. Antagonism of this receptor causes relaxation of the bladder neck muscles. In patients with urge incontinence due to detrusor overactivity, relaxation of the bladder neck muscles would likely worsen symptoms as there would be no resistance to counteract bladder contraction.

C) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of beta-3 adrenergic receptors found on smooth muscle cells of the urinary bladder promotes detrusor muscle relaxation, thereby delaying the need for micturition. Antagonism of these receptors would cause increased detrusor contraction and would worsen symptoms in patients with urge incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

While beta-2 agonism would cause detrusor muscle relaxation of the bladder, it is not commonly used to treat urge incontinence. Beta-2 adrenergic agonists (e.g., albuterol or salmeterol) are used to manage asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, as they are very potent bronchodilators.

E) INCORRECT:

Agonism of muscarinic M3 receptors causes bladder contraction. Drugs such as bethanechol stimulate expulsion of urine and are commonly used for patients with overflow urinary incontinence. Unlike urge incontinence, overflow incontinence usually causes continuous dribbling and is not typically associated with a sudden urge to void.

F) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic receptor antagonists such as rocuronium are primarily used as muscle relaxants intraoperatively. Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors are found in presynaptic neurons of the autonomic ganglia, and postsynaptic neurons of the neuromuscular junction of skeletal muscles. Bladder contraction is regulated by smooth muscle, not skeletal muscle; so drugs affecting the nicotinic receptor pathway would not be effective at improving symptoms of urge incontinence.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has urge incontinence, as evidenced by her sudden urge to urinate resulting in frequent involuntary loss of small amounts of urine and nocturia. Because she has failed conservative treatment, she qualifies for pharmacologic treatment. Oxybutynin would be an appropriate first-line medication.
